00059 #include <stdlib.h>
00060 #include <string.h>
00061 #include <openssl/e_os2.h>
00062 #include <openssl/md5.h>
00063 
00064 #ifndef MD5_LONG_LOG2
00065 #define MD5_LONG_LOG2 2 /* default to 32 bits */
00066 #endif
00067 
00068 #ifdef MD5_ASM
00069 # if defined(__i386) || defined(__i386__) || defined(_M_IX86) || defined(__INTEL__)
00070 #  define md5_block_host_order md5_block_asm_host_order
00071 # elif defined(__sparc) && defined(OPENSSL_SYS_ULTRASPARC)
00072    void md5_block_asm_data_order_aligned (MD5_CTX *c, const MD5_LONG *p,int num);
00073 #  define HASH_BLOCK_DATA_ORDER_ALIGNED md5_block_asm_data_order_aligned
00074 # endif
00075 #endif
00076 
00077 void md5_block_host_order (MD5_CTX *c, const void *p,int num);
00078 void md5_block_data_order (MD5_CTX *c, const void *p,int num);
00079 
00080 #if defined(__i386) || defined(__i386__) || defined(_M_IX86) || defined(__INTEL__)
00081 /*
00082  * *_block_host_order is expected to handle aligned data while
00083  * *_block_data_order - unaligned. As algorithm and host (x86)
00084  * are in this case of the same "endianness" these two are
00085  * otherwise indistinguishable. But normally you don't want to
00086  * call the same function because unaligned access in places
00087  * where alignment is expected is usually a "Bad Thing". Indeed,
00088  * on RISCs you get punished with BUS ERROR signal or *severe*
00089  * performance degradation. Intel CPUs are in turn perfectly
00090  * capable of loading unaligned data without such drastic side
00091  * effect. Yes, they say it's slower than aligned load, but no
00092  * exception is generated and therefore performance degradation
00093  * is *incomparable* with RISCs. What we should weight here is
00094  * costs of unaligned access against costs of aligning data.
00095  * According to my measurements allowing unaligned access results
00096  * in ~9% performance improvement on Pentium II operating at
00097  * 266MHz. I won't be surprised if the difference will be higher
00098  * on faster systems:-)
00099  *
00100  *              <appro@fy.chalmers.se>
00101  */
00102 #define md5_block_data_order md5_block_host_order
00103 #endif
00104 
00105 #define DATA_ORDER_IS_LITTLE_ENDIAN
00106 
00107 #define HASH_LONG       MD5_LONG
00108 #define HASH_LONG_LOG2      MD5_LONG_LOG2
00109 #define HASH_CTX        MD5_CTX
00110 #define HASH_CBLOCK     MD5_CBLOCK
00111 #define HASH_LBLOCK     MD5_LBLOCK
00112 #define HASH_UPDATE     MD5_Update
00113 #define HASH_TRANSFORM      MD5_Transform
00114 #define HASH_FINAL      MD5_Final
00115 #define HASH_MAKE_STRING(c,s)   do {    \
00116     unsigned long ll;       \
00117     ll=(c)->A; HOST_l2c(ll,(s));    \
00118     ll=(c)->B; HOST_l2c(ll,(s));    \
00119     ll=(c)->C; HOST_l2c(ll,(s));    \
00120     ll=(c)->D; HOST_l2c(ll,(s));    \
00121     } while (0)
00122 #define HASH_BLOCK_HOST_ORDER   md5_block_host_order
00123 #if !defined(L_ENDIAN) || defined(md5_block_data_order)
00124 #define HASH_BLOCK_DATA_ORDER   md5_block_data_order
00125 /*
00126  * Little-endians (Intel and Alpha) feel better without this.
00127  * It looks like memcpy does better job than generic
00128  * md5_block_data_order on copying-n-aligning input data.
00129  * But frankly speaking I didn't expect such result on Alpha.
00130  * On the other hand I've got this with egcs-1.0.2 and if
00131  * program is compiled with another (better?) compiler it
00132  * might turn out other way around.
00133  *
00134  *              <appro@fy.chalmers.se>
00135  */
00136 #endif
00137 
00138 #include "md32_common.h"
00139 
00140 /*
00141 #define F(x,y,z)    (((x) & (y))  |  ((~(x)) & (z)))
00142 #define G(x,y,z)    (((x) & (z))  |  ((y) & (~(z))))
00143 */
00144 
00145 /* As pointed out by Wei Dai <weidai@eskimo.com>, the above can be
00146  * simplified to the code below.  Wei attributes these optimizations
00147  * to Peter Gutmann's SHS code, and he attributes it to Rich Schroeppel.
00148  */
00149 #define F(b,c,d)    ((((c) ^ (d)) & (b)) ^ (d))
00150 #define G(b,c,d)    ((((b) ^ (c)) & (d)) ^ (c))
00151 #define H(b,c,d)    ((b) ^ (c) ^ (d))
00152 #define I(b,c,d)    (((~(d)) | (b)) ^ (c))
00153 
00154 #define R0(a,b,c,d,k,s,t) { \
00155     a+=((k)+(t)+F((b),(c),(d))); \
00156     a=ROTATE(a,s); \
00157     a+=b; };\
00158 
00159 #define R1(a,b,c,d,k,s,t) { \
00160     a+=((k)+(t)+G((b),(c),(d))); \
00161     a=ROTATE(a,s); \
00162     a+=b; };
00163 
00164 #define R2(a,b,c,d,k,s,t) { \
00165     a+=((k)+(t)+H((b),(c),(d))); \
00166     a=ROTATE(a,s); \
00167     a+=b; };
00168 
00169 #define R3(a,b,c,d,k,s,t) { \
00170     a+=((k)+(t)+I((b),(c),(d))); \
00171     a=ROTATE(a,s); \
00172     a+=b; };
